slides.title: Introduction
content: Large language models enable complex, multi-step tasks
Agents are LLM-powered systems for workflow automation
Guide provides practical best practices for building agents
Aims to help product and engineering teams start confidently

slides.title: What is an Agent?
content: Systems that independently accomplish tasks on user's behalf
Leverage LLMs to manage workflow execution and decisions
Have access to tools to interact with external systems
Not simple chatbots or single-turn LLMs

slides.title: When to Build an Agent
content: Prioritize workflows resistant to traditional automation
Complex decision-making with nuanced judgment
Difficult-to-maintain rules with extensive rulesets
Heavy reliance on unstructured data interpretation

slides.title: Agent Design Foundations
content: Core components: Model, Tools, Instructions
Model selection based on task complexity and cost
Tools extend capabilities (Data, Action, Orchestration)
Clear instructions reduce ambiguity and improve execution

slides.title: Orchestration Patterns
content: Single-agent systems: Manage complexity with tools
Multi-agent systems: Manager or Decentralized patterns
Manager pattern: Central coordination of specialized agents
Decentralized pattern: Peer agents hand off tasks

slides.title: Guardrails
content: Layered defense: LLM-based, rules-based, moderation
Types: Relevance, Safety, PII filters, Tool safeguards
Output validation for brand alignment
Plan for human intervention in high-risk scenarios

slides.title: Conclusion
content: Agents automate complex workflows with autonomy
Start small with strong foundations and guardrails
Iterative approach for successful deployment
Combine intelligence with safety measures
